Knowledge Point: Reduplication in terms of \isi{lexeme formation} is described in §\ref{Para_4.1} while \isi{lexeme interpretation} is discussed in §\ref{Para_4.2}. This discussion is followed by a comparison of \isi{reduplication} across different \ili{eastern Malay varieties} in §\ref{Para_4.3}. The main points of this chapter are summarized in §\ref{Para_4.4}.

Knowledge Point: A phonological approach to \isi{reduplication} is \citegen[436]{Marantz.1982} pros\-odic template model which views \isi{reduplication} as “normal \isi{affixation}” with “one uniq\-ue feature”, i.e. “the resemblance of the added material to the stem being reduplicated”. More specifically, “every \isi{reduplication} process may be characterized by a ‘skeleton’ of some sort”, either a phonemic melody, “a C-V skeleton, a syllabic skeleton, or a skeleton of morpheme symbols” (\citeyear*[439]{Marantz.1982}). The four-tiered representation in (\ref{Example_4.1}), taken from {\citet[437]{Marantz.1982}}, illustrates how the segments of the four skeleta are linked to each other.

Knowledge Point: Full \isi{reduplication} of morphological words in Papuan Malay is illustrated with the two examples in (\ref{Example_4.2}): \isi{reduplication} of the root \textitbf{dorang} ‘\textsc{3pl}’, resulting in \textitbf{dorang{\Tilde}dorang} ‘\textsc{rdp}{\Tilde}\textsc{3pl}’ in (\ref{Example_4.2a}), and \isi{reduplication} of the derived word \textitbf{tingka\-tang} ‘level’ (\textitbf{tingkat}\-\textitbf{ang} ‘floor-\textsc{pat}’), resulting in \textitbf{tingkatang{\Tilde}tingkat\-ang}

In each case, the content of the reduplicative affix is obtained by copying the phonemic melody of the base over the morphemic skeleton of the reduplicating affix. This applies to roots as in (\ref{Example_4.2a}) as well as to derived words as in (\ref{Example_4.2b}).

Knowledge Point: In Papuan Malay, only words are reduplicated; bound morphemes such as prefixes are never reduplicated (see \tabref{Table_4.1} in §\ref{Para_4.1.1.1}). Full \isi{reduplication} is attested for content words (§\ref{Para_4.1.1.1}) and some function words (§\ref{Para_4.1.1.2}). The corpus also includes a few reduplicated items that do not have an unreduplicated single base (§\ref{Para_4.1.1.3}). Reduplication of reduplicated bases is unattested.

Knowledge Point: \caption [Reduplication of content words]{Reduplication of content words\footnote{As discussed in §\ref{Para_4.2}, \isi{reduplication} conveys a variety of different meanings. Hence, a reduplicated item can receive different interpretations, depending on the context. The reduplicated \isi{noun} \textitbf{tulang{\Tilde}tulang}, for instance, can receive the following readings: ‘any one of the bones’, ‘different kinds of bones’, ‘all of the bones’. Hence, no translation is given for the reduplicated items in \tabref{Table_4.1}. The same applies to \tabref{Table_4.2} in §\ref{Para_4.1.1.2}.}}\label{Table_4.1}

Knowledge Point: Reduplication of content words is demonstrated with the three examples in (\ref{Example_4.3}) to (\ref{Example_4.5}). Reduplication of a \isi{noun} is illustrated in (\ref{Example_4.3}); in this context reduplicated \textitbf{ade} ‘younger sibling’ conveys plurality. The utterance in (\ref{Example_4.4}) includes a reduplicated \isi{verb}; in this context, \textitbf{lari} ‘run’ expresses \isi{continuation}. And the elicited example in (\ref{Example_4.5}) illustrates \isi{reduplication} of an ad\isi{verb}; in this context \isi{prohibitive} \textitbf{jangang} ‘\textsc{neg.imp}, don’t’ denotes \isi{intensity}. The three examples illustrate only three of the different meanings expressed with \isi{reduplication}. Depending on the context, a reduplicated \isi{noun} can also signal \isi{repetition}, to name just one other meaning aspect. Along similar lines, a reduplicated \isi{verb} can also express \isi{aimlessness}, among other meanings. This variety of different meanings is discussed in detail in §\ref{Para_4.2}.
Content 1: \gll jadi saya, saya deng sa pu \textbf{ade~ade} tinggal di ruma | \gls so 1SG 1SG with 1SG POSS RDP~ySb stay at house | \glt Plurality: ‘so I, I and my \textbf{younger siblings} stayed at the house’
Content 2: \gll ... tapi \textbf{jangang~jangang} hujang di tenga jalang | \gls ... but RDP~NEG.IMP rain at middle walk | \glt Intensity: ‘[I want to go to (my) gardens,] but \textbf{let’s hope} it \textbf{won’t} rain in the middle of the way’
Content 3: \gll jadi saya, saya deng sa pu \textbf{ade~ade} tinggal di ruma | \gls so 1SG 1SG with 1SG POSS RDP~ySb stay at house | \glt Plurality: ‘so I, I and my \textbf{younger siblings} stayed at the house’
Content 4: \gll kitong dua \textbf{lari~lari} sampe di Martewar | \gls 1PL two RDP~run reach at Martewar | \glt Continuation: ‘the two of us \textbf{kept running} all the way to Martewar’
Content 5: \gll ... tapi \textbf{jangang~jangang} hujang di tenga jalang | \gls ... but RDP~NEG.IMP rain at middle walk | \glt Intensity: ‘[I want to go to (my) gardens,] but \textbf{let’s hope} it \textbf{won’t} rain in the middle of the way’

Knowledge Point: Reduplication of three different types of functions words and the different meaning aspects conveyed is illustrated in (\ref{Example_4.6}) to (\ref{Example_4.8}): personal pronouns in (\ref{Example_4.6}), locatives in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_4.7}), and interrogatives in (\ref{Example_4.8}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{kamu~kamu} ini bangung, bangung | \gls RDP~2PL D.PROX wake.up wake.up | \glt Collectivity: ‘\textbf{you all} here wake-up!, wake-up!’
Content 2: \gll ... sa tra perna lari ke \textbf{siapa~siapa} | \gls ... 1SG NEG once run to RDP~who | \glt Intensity: ‘[even (when) my children were already sick,] I’ve never run to \textbf{anyone} (for black-magic help)’

Content 4: \gll ko lari suda ke \textbf{sana~sana} | \gls 2SG run already to RDP~LOC.DIST | \glt Diversity: ‘you run to \textbf{somewhere} over there!’
Content 5: \gll ... sa tra perna lari ke \textbf{siapa~siapa} | \gls ... 1SG NEG once run to RDP~who | \glt Intensity: ‘[even (when) my children were already sick,] I’ve never run to \textbf{anyone} (for black-magic help)’

Knowledge Point: In Papuan Malay, the reduplicant is a closed heavy syllable which is prefixed to the stem from which it borrows the phonemic melody and C-V skeleton, as shown in (\ref{Example_4.9}). In (\ref{Example_4.9a}), for example, the initial closed syllable [\textstyleChCharisSIL{bɐp}] is copied over the reduplicating syllabic skeleton. With vowel-initial stems, the initial VC is copied over the reduplicating syllabic skeleton. This is shown in (\ref{Example_4.9c}) with the initial VC [\textstyleChCharisSIL{an}] which is copied over the prefixed CVC syllable. These examples also show that the prefixed syllable does not take into account the \isi{syllable structure} of the base.

Knowledge Point: The meaning aspects of reduplicated Papuan Malay content words are examined in §\ref{Para_4.2.1} to §\ref{Para_4.2.4}, those of reduplicated function words in §\ref{Para_4.2.5}. The underlying general meaning or \isi{gesamtbedeutung} of \isi{reduplication} is explored in §\ref{Para_4.2.6}.

Knowledge Point: Across languages, \isi{reduplication} of nouns has been found to express a variety of meanings such as “number [\ldots], case, distributivity, \isi{indefiniteness}, reciprocity, size (diminutive or augmentative), and \isi{associative} qualities” {\citep{Rubino.2013}}. In Papuan Malay, the following meaning aspects are attested: \isi{collectivity} and diversity (§\ref{Para_4.2.1.1}), \isi{repetition} (§\ref{Para_4.2.1.2}), and \isi{indefiniteness} (§\ref{Para_4.2.1.3}). Reduplicated nouns can also undergo an \isi{interpretational shift} and receive a verbal or adverbial reading (§\ref{Para_4.2.1.4}).

Knowledge Point: A major function of \isi{noun} \isi{reduplication} is to signal plurality, given that in Papuan Malay bare nouns are not marked for number. Instead, speakers express plurality as deemed necessary. Depending on the context, the lexical item \textitbf{ana} ‘child’, for instance, could also be read as ‘children’. One strategy to express plurality overtly is the \isi{reduplication} of nouns. Overall, however, speakers use \isi{reduplication} only when an unambiguous plural reading is important to them and when the context does not allow such an unambiguous interpretation. (Alternative strategies to indicate plurality are \isi{modification} with a \isi{numeral} or \isi{quantifier}, or with a plural personal \isi{pronoun}; see §\ref{Para_8.2.3} and §\ref{Para_6.2.2}, respectively.)
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Cross-linguistically, three types of plurality have been identified which are encoded by \isi{noun} \isi{reduplication} \citep[561]{Wiltshire.1978}: \isi{collectivity}, diversity (or variety), and distributivity.\footnote{\citet[561]{Wiltshire.1978} refer to “\isi{collectivity}” as “simple plurality”.} Of these three types, Papuan Malay uses two, namely \isi{collectivity} as in (\ref{Example_4.10}) and (\ref{Example_4.11}), and diversity as in (\ref{Example_4.12}) and (\ref{Example_4.13}). Another type of plurality is \isi{indefiniteness} \citep{Rubino.2013}, which is also found in Papuan Malay, as demonstrated in (\ref{Example_4.16}) and (\ref{Example_4.17}) in §\ref{Para_4.2.1.3} (p. \pageref{Example_4.16}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{ana~ana} su pergi kerja, \textbf{ana~ana} su kawing | \gls RDP~child already go work RDP~child already marry.inofficially | \glt [Complaint of a lonely couple:] ‘\textbf{all (our) children} already went to work (elsewhere), \textbf{all (our) children} are already married’
Content 2: \gll e, \textbf{orang~orang} itu dong mara~mara | \gls hey! RDP~person D.DIST 3PL RDP~feel.angry(.about) | \glt ‘hey, \textbf{all those people}, they’ll be really angry (with you)’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{bua~bua} di sini banyak | \gls RDP~fruit at L.PROX many | \glt ‘there are a many \textbf{different kinds of fruit (trees)} here’ (Lit. ‘\textbf{the various fruit (trees)} here are many’)
Content 4: Not found
Content 5: \gll baru titip di, ini, \textbf{om~om} dorang | \gls and.then deposit at D.PROX RDP~uncle 3PL | \glt ‘leave (the letter) with, what’s-his-name, \textbf{any one of the uncles} and his family’
Content 6: \gll dia lewat pante \textbf{malam~malam} | \gls 3SG pass.by coast RDP~night | \glt ‘he drove along the beach \textbf{at some (point in) the evening}’

Knowledge Point: Reduplication of nouns most often indicates \isi{collectivity} in the sense of ``all \textsc{base}'', as shown with \textitbf{ana{\Tilde}ana} ‘children’ in (\ref{Example_4.10}) and \textitbf{orang{\Tilde}orang} ‘people’ in (\ref{Example_4.11}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{ana~ana} su pergi kerja, \textbf{ana~ana} su kawing | \gls RDP~child already go work RDP~child already marry.inofficially | \glt [Complaint of a lonely couple:] ‘\textbf{all (our) children} already went to work (elsewhere), \textbf{all (our) children} are already married’
Content 2: \gll e, \textbf{orang~orang} itu dong mara~mara | \gls hey! RDP~person D.DIST 3PL RDP~feel.angry(.about) | \glt ‘hey, \textbf{all those people}, they’ll be really angry (with you)’

Knowledge Point: Less often, reduplicated nouns signal diversity such as \textitbf{bua{\Tilde}bua} ‘various fruit (trees)’ in (\ref{Example_4.12}), or \textitbf{pohong{\Tilde}pohong} ‘various trees’ in (\ref{Example_4.13}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{bua~bua} di sini banyak | \gls RDP~fruit at L.PROX many | \glt ‘there are a many \textbf{different kinds of fruit (trees)} here’ (Lit. ‘\textbf{the various fruit (trees)} here are many’)

Knowledge Point: Reduplication of nouns denoting periods of the day can indicate \isi{repetition}. This is illustrated with \textitbf{pagi{\Tilde}pagi} ‘every morning’ in (\ref{Example_4.14}), and \textitbf{malam{\Tilde}malam} ‘every evening’ in (\ref{Example_4.15}). (For alternative readings of reduplicated nouns expressing time divisions, see (\ref{Example_4.17}) in §\ref{Para_4.2.1.3}, p. \pageref{Example_4.17}, and (\ref{Example_4.23}) and (\ref{Example_4.24}) in §\ref{Para_4.2.1.4}, p. \pageref{Example_4.23}.)
Content 1: \gll \textbf{pagi~pagi} biking te | \gls RDP~morning make tea | \glt ‘\textbf{every morning} (they) made tea’
Content 2: \gll ko jangang ikut~ikut orang tua \textbf{malam~malam} | \gls 2SG NEG.IMP RDP~follow person be.old RDP~night | \glt ‘don’t keep hanging out with the grown-ups \textbf{every evening}’
Content 3: \gll dia lewat pante \textbf{malam~malam} | \gls 3SG pass.by coast RDP~night | \glt ‘he drove along the beach \textbf{at some (point in) the evening}’
Content 4: Not found
Content 5: \gll ... \textbf{pagi~pagi} jam lima sa su masuk di kamar | \gls ... RDP~morning hour five 1SG already enter at room | \glt [About disciplining ill-behaved teenagers:] ‘[tonight I’ll still sleep,] (but tomorrow) \textbf{early in the morning} at five o’clock I will already have gone into (their) room’
Content 6: \gll {\textbf{malam~malam}} Ise bawa pulang dia pi tidor dengang de punya mama | \gls RDP~night Ise bring go.home 3SG go sleep with\gls 3SG POSS mother | \glt [About a crying child:] ‘\textbf{late at night} Ise brought (her) home so that she (would) go and sleep with her mother’

Knowledge Point: Depending on the context, reduplicated nouns may signal \isi{indefiniteness} by referring to an unspecified group member, in the sense of ``any'' or "some''. This is illustrated with \textitbf{om{\Tilde}om} ‘any one of the uncles’ in (\ref{Example_4.16}), and \textitbf{malam{\Tilde}malam} ‘at some point in the evening’ in (\ref{Example_4.17}). (For alternative interpretations of reduplicated nouns signaling time divisions, see (\ref{Example_4.14}) and (\ref{Example_4.15}) in §\ref{Para_4.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_4.14}, and (\ref{Example_4.23}) and (\ref{Example_4.24}) in §\ref{Para_4.2.1.4}, p. \pageref{Example_4.23}.)

Content 2: \gll dia lewat pante \textbf{malam~malam} | \gls 3SG pass.by coast RDP~night | \glt ‘he drove along the beach \textbf{at some (point in) the evening}’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{pagi~pagi} biking te | \gls RDP~morning make tea | \glt ‘\textbf{every morning} (they) made tea’

RDP~morning hour five 1SG already enter at room | \glt [About disciplining ill-behaved teenagers:] ‘[tonight I’ll still sleep,] (but tomorrow) \textbf{early in the morning} at five o’clock I will already have gone into (their) room’

Knowledge Point: Reduplicated nouns can also undergo, what generally-speaking \citet[212]{Booij.2007} calls, an “\isi{interpretational shift}” or “type coercion”. In Papuan Malay, such a shift can result in a stative verbal reading of reduplicated nouns as in (\ref{Example_4.18}) to (\ref{Example_4.20}), or in an adverbial reading as in (\ref{Example_4.21}) to (\ref{Example_4.24}), depending on the larger linguistic context.
Content 1: \gll waktu itu sa masi \textbf{ana~ana} | \gls time D.DIST 1SG still RDP~child | \glt ‘at that time I was still \textbf{quite small}’
Content 2: \gll masi \textbf{rawa~rawa} | \gls still RDP~swamp | \glt [About a road building project:] ‘(the area is) still \textbf{swampy}’
Content 3: \gll sa tunjuk \textbf{depang~depang} muka, blajar untuk mandiri | \gls 1SG show RDP~front front study for stand.alone | \glt ‘I point \textbf{right into} (their) faces (and tell them), ``study to become independent'''
Content 4: \gll {\textbf{malam~malam}} Ise bawa pulang dia pi tidor dengang de punya mama | \gls RDP~night Ise bring go.home 3SG go sleep with\gls 3SG POSS mother | \glt [About a crying child:] ‘\textbf{late at night} Ise brought (her) home so that she (would) go and sleep with her mother’

Knowledge Point: Interpretational shift resulting in a stative verbal reading of reduplicated nouns usually applies to reduplicated kinship terms, taking the predicate slot in nonverbal clauses. This is illustrated with \textitbf{ana} ‘child’ in (\ref{Example_4.18}) and \textitbf{tete} ‘grandfather’ in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_4.19}). In this context, the reduplicated nouns receive a stative verbal rather than a nominal reading. That is, referring to specific age groups, they designate pertinent attributes of their base words, as in \textitbf{ana{\Tilde}ana} ‘be quite small’ (literally ‘\textsc{rdp}{\Tilde}child’) in (\ref{Example_4.18}), or \textitbf{tete{\Tilde}tete} ‘be quite old’ (literally ‘\textsc{rdp}{\Tilde}grandfather’) in (\ref{Example_4.19}). In addition, the corpus contains one example in which a non-\isi{kinship term}, namely the common \isi{noun} \textitbf{rawa} ‘swamp’, undergoes a similar \isi{interpretational shift}, receiving the stative verbal reading in \textitbf{rawa{\Tilde}rawa} ‘be swampy’, as shown in (\ref{Example_4.20}).
Content 1: \gll waktu itu sa masi \textbf{ana~ana} | \gls time D.DIST 1SG still RDP~child | \glt ‘at that time I was still \textbf{quite small}’
Content 2: \gll pace {ni} de {su} \textbf{tete~tete} tapi masi maing deng ana~ana muda | \gls man D.PROX 3SG already RDP~grandfather but still\gls play with RDP~child be.young | \glt ‘this guy, he’s already \textbf{quite old} but he still hangs out with the young people’
Content 3: \gll waktu itu sa masi \textbf{ana~ana} | \gls time D.DIST 1SG still RDP~child | \glt ‘at that time I was still \textbf{quite small}’
Content 4: \gll pace {ni} de {su} \textbf{tete~tete} tapi masi maing deng ana~ana muda | \gls man D.PROX 3SG already RDP~grandfather but still\gls play with RDP~child be.young | \glt ‘this guy, he’s already \textbf{quite old} but he still hangs out with the young people’
Content 5: \gll masi \textbf{rawa~rawa} | \gls still RDP~swamp | \glt [About a road building project:] ‘(the area is) still \textbf{swampy}’

Knowledge Point: Interpretational shift can also affect reduplicated location nouns or nouns denoting periods of the day, with the reduplicated nouns receiving an intensified or emphatic adverbial reading. This is illustrated with the location nouns \textitbf{depang} ‘front’ in (\ref{Example_4.21}) and \textitbf{samping} ‘side’ in (\ref{Example_4.22}), and the temporal nouns \textitbf{pagi} ‘morning’ in (\ref{Example_4.23}) and \textitbf{malam} ‘night’ in (\ref{Example_4.24}). (For alternative readings of reduplicated nouns designating time divisions, see (\ref{Example_4.14}) and (\ref{Example_4.15}) in §\ref{Para_4.2.1.2}, p. \pageref{Example_4.14}, and (\ref{Example_4.17}) in §\ref{Para_4.2.1.3}, p. \pageref{Example_4.17}.)
Content 1: \gll sa tunjuk \textbf{depang~depang} muka, blajar untuk mandiri | \gls 1SG show RDP~front front study for stand.alone | \glt ‘I point \textbf{right into} (their) faces (and tell them), ``study to become independent'''
Content 2: \gll jalang di \textbf{samping~samping} itu pagar itu | \gls walk at RDP~side D.DIST fence D.DIST | \glt ‘(he/she) walked \textbf{right next to}, what’s-its-name, that fence’
Content 3: \gll ... \textbf{pagi~pagi} jam lima sa su masuk di kamar | \gls ... RDP~morning hour five 1SG already enter at room | \glt [About disciplining ill-behaved teenagers:] ‘[tonight I’ll still sleep,] (but tomorrow) \textbf{early in the morning} at five o’clock I will already have gone into (their) room’
Content 4: \gll {\textbf{malam~malam}} Ise bawa pulang dia pi tidor dengang de punya mama | \gls RDP~night Ise bring go.home 3SG go sleep with\gls 3SG POSS mother | \glt [About a crying child:] ‘\textbf{late at night} Ise brought (her) home so that she (would) go and sleep with her mother’

Content 6: \gll ko jangang ikut~ikut orang tua \textbf{malam~malam} | \gls 2SG NEG.IMP RDP~follow person be.old RDP~night | \glt ‘don’t keep hanging out with the grown-ups \textbf{every evening}’

Knowledge Point: Cross-linguistically, \isi{reduplication} of verbs tends to encode meaning aspects such as “distribution of an argument, tense, aspect (continued or repeated occurrence; completion; inchoativity), \isi{attenuation}, \isi{intensity}, transitivity (valence, object defocusing), or reciprocity” (\citealt{Rubino.2013}; see also \citealt[561]{Wiltshire.1978}). In Papuan Malay, the following meaning aspects are attested: \isi{continuation}, \isi{repetition}, and habit (§\ref{Para_4.2.2.1}), \isi{collectivity} and diversity (§\ref{Para_4.2.2.2}), \isi{intensity} (§\ref{Para_4.2.2.3}), \isi{immediacy} (§\ref{Para_4.2.2.4}), \isi{aimlessness} (§\ref{Para_4.2.2.5}), \isi{attenuation} (4.2.2.6), and \isi{imitation} (§\ref{Para_4.2.2.7}). Reduplicated verbs can also undergo \isi{interpretational shift}, in that they can receive a nominal or adverbial reading (§\ref{Para_4.2.2.8}).

Knowledge Point: A major function of \isi{verb} \isi{reduplication} is to indicate \isi{continuation}, \isi{repetition}, or habit. The function of signaling \isi{continuation} is demonstrated with a dynamic \isi{verb} in (\ref{Example_4.25}) and a stative \isi{verb} in the elicited example in (\ref{Example_4.26}). The function of signaling \isi{repetition} of an action is shown in (\ref{Example_4.27}).
Content 1: \gll ... ada setang datang \textbf{ganggu~ganggu} kitorang | \gls ... exist evil.spirit come RDP~disturb 1PL | \glt ‘[when (we) sleep at night,] there is an evil spirit (who) comes and \textbf{continuously bothers} (us)’
Content 2: \gll sa pu temang de \textbf{sakit~sakit} di Dok-Dua | \gls 1SG POSS friend 3SG RDP~be.sick at Dok-Dua | \glt ‘my friend is being \textbf{sick continuously} in the Dok-Dua (hospital)’
Content 3: \gll baru de pi \textbf{bicara~bicara} sa begini | \gls and.then 3SG go RDP~speak 1SG like.this | \glt ‘but then he went to \textbf{talk} about me like this \textbf{again and again}’

Knowledge Point: As an extension of marking \isi{continuation} or \isi{repetition}, reduplicated verbs may also signal habit, as shown in (\ref{Example_4.28}).
Content 1: \gll begitu de besar baru de \textbf{nakal~nakal} begini | \gls like.that 3SG be.big and.then 3SG RDP~be.mischievous like.this | \glt ‘he grew up like that, and now he’s \textbf{mischievous} like this \textbf{all the time}’

Knowledge Point: Verb \isi{reduplication} may also indicate \isi{collectivity} or diversity of the clausal subject. The function of signaling \isi{collectivity} is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_4.29}) and (\ref{Example_4.30}), while the diversity-marking function of reduplicated verbs is shown in the elicited examples in (\ref{Example_4.31}) and (\ref{Example_4.32}).
Content 1: \gll dong taru piring~piring kaleng yang \textbf{piring} yang \textbf{bagus~bagus} | \gls 3PL put RDP~plate tin.can REL plate REL RDP~be.good | \glt [About honoring guests:] ‘they place tin plates (in front of them) that are \textbf{plates} that are \textbf{all good}’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{pisang} \textbf{Sorong} sana tu, iii, \textbf{besar~besar} manis | \gls banana Sorong L.DIST D.DIST oh! RDP~be.big be.sweet | \glt ‘those \textbf{bananas (from) Sorong} over there, oooh, (they) are \textbf{all big} (and) sweet’
Content 3: \gll ko pu \textbf{kwe} \textbf{kras~kras} | \gls 2SG POSS cake RDP~be.harsh | \glt ‘your \textbf{various cakes} are \textbf{hard}’
Content 4: \gll \textbf{mobil} di jalang \textbf{rusak~rusak} karna banjir | \gls car at walk RDP~be.damaged because flooding | \glt ‘the \textbf{various cars} in the street were \textbf{broken} because of the flooding’

Knowledge Point: Also, quite commonly reduplicated verbs signal \isi{intensity}. In such cases, reduplicated dynamic verbs receive the reading ``\textsc{base} intensely'', as in (\ref{Example_4.33}) and (\ref{Example_4.34}), while \isi{reduplication} of stative verbs translates with ``very \textsc{base}'', as in (\ref{Example_4.35}) and (\ref{Example_4.36}).
Content 1: \gll baru dia tertawa, de \textbf{tertawa~tertawa} | \gls and.then 3SG laugh 3SG RDP~laugh | \glt ‘but then he laughed, he \textbf{laughed intensely}’
Content 2: \gll orang \textbf{bertriak~triak} tu | \gls person RDP~scream D.DIST | \glt ‘the people were really \textbf{screaming} \textbf{intensely}’
Content 3: \gll sa jalang sampe sa su \textbf{swak~swak} | \gls 1SG walk until 1SG already RDP~be.exhausted | \glt ‘I walked until I was already \textbf{very exhausted}’
Content 4: \gll ... dong tu \textbf{pintar~pintar} | \gls ... 3PL D.DIST RDP~be.clever | \gls \glt ‘... they (EMPH) are \textbf{very clever}’

Knowledge Point: When reduplicated verbs are negated with \textitbf{tra} ‘\textsc{neg}’ or \textitbf{jangang} ‘don’t’, they express an intensified negative in the sense of ``not \textsc{base} at all'', as shown in (\ref{Example_4.37}) and (\ref{Example_4.38}).
Content 1: \gll sa \textbf{tra} \textbf{takut~takut} siapa pun | \gls 1SG NEG RDP~feel.afraid(.of) who even | \glt ‘I’m \textbf{not afraid at all} of anybody’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{jangang} \textbf{bli~bli} di sini, ini su malam | \gls NEG.IMP RDP~buy at L.PROX D.PROX already night | \glt ‘(you) \textbf{shouldn’t buy} (your sweets at the kiosk) here \textbf{at all} (because) it is already night’

Knowledge Point: Reduplicated verbs can indicate \isi{immediacy} in the sense of ``as soon as \textsc{base}''. This is illustrated with the reduplicated dynamic verbs in the elicited examples in (\ref{Example_4.39}) and (\ref{Example_4.40}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{pulang~pulang} dari kantor pace de tidor | \gls RDP~go.home from office man 3SG sleep | \glt ‘\textbf{as soon as} (he) \textbf{came home} from the office, the man slept’
Content 2: \gll mace ni \textbf{datang~datang} trus de makang | \gls woman D.PROX RDP~come next 3SG eat | \glt ‘\textbf{as soon as} this woman \textbf{arrived}, she ate’

Knowledge Point: Quite often, \isi{reduplication} adds the connotation of \isi{aimlessness} or casualness. That is, the reduplicated \isi{verb} may signal that an activity is done repeatedly without a specific goal, as in (\ref{Example_4.41}) and (\ref{Example_4.42}).
Content 1: \gll sa itu sa pegang sagu sa makang \textbf{jalang~jalang} | \gls 1SG D.DIST 1SG hold sago 1SG eat RDP~walk | \glt ‘as for me, I was holding (some) sago, I ate (it) while \textbf{strolling around}’
Content 2: \gll malam kitong \textbf{duduk~duduk} kitong \textbf{menyanyi~menyanyi} | \gls night 1PL RDP~sit 1PL RDP~sing | \glt ‘in the evening we were \textbf{sitting around}, we were \textbf{singing casually}’

Knowledge Point: Depending on the context, reduplicated stative verbs may signal \isi{attenuation} in the sense of ``rather \textsc{base}'', as demonstrated in (\ref{Example_4.43}) and (\ref{Example_4.44}).
Content 1: \gll ... {biking} {macang} kam {pu} Jayapura pu sayur gnemo yang \textbf{pahit~pahit} itu | \gls ... make variety 2PL POSS Jayapura POSS vegetable\gls melinjo REL RDP~be.bitter D.DIST | \glt ‘[then she asked, ‘you don’t fear the bitter (taste of melinjos)?, then mama Pawla said,] ``do you think this (melinjo) is like your Jayapura melinjo vegetable which is \textbf{somewhat bitter}?'''
Content 2: \gll badang {\textbf{kurus~kurus},} rambut {ini} {tebal,} de pu kuku ini \textbf{panjang~panjang}, kaki \textbf{kurus~kurus} | \gls body RDP~be.thin hair D.PROX be.thick 3SG POSS\gls digit.nail D.PROX RDP~be.long foot RDP~be.thin | \glt ‘(his) body was \textbf{somewhat thin}, (his) hair was thick, his fingernails were \textbf{rather long}, (and his) legs were \textbf{rather thin}’

Knowledge Point: Reduplicated verbs may also mark \isi{imitation} in the sense of ``something is an \isi{imitation} of X'' or ``something is similar to X''. This is illustrated with the dynamic verbs in (\ref{Example_4.45}) and (\ref{Example_4.46}), and the stative verbs in the elicited examples in (\ref{Example_4.47}) and (\ref{Example_4.48}).
Content 1: \gll sa tendang dia di kaki sampe de \textbf{lari~lari} \textbf{babi} | \gls 1SG kick 3SG at leg until 3SG RDP~run pig | \glt ‘I kicked him against (his) lower leg with the result that he \textbf{staggered}’ (Lit. ‘he \textbf{ran~ran} (like) \textbf{a pig} (which has been shot)’)
Content 2: \gll dia \textbf{mati~mati} \textbf{ayam} | \gls 3SG RDP~die chicken | \glt ‘he had an \textbf{epileptic seizure}’ (Lit. ‘he \textbf{died~died} (like) \textbf{a chicken}’; that is, he was shaking like a chicken with its head cut off)
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: \gll prempuang itu de pu kulit \textbf{hitam~hitam} \textbf{panta} \textbf{blanga} | \gls woman D.DIST 3SG POSS skin RDP~be.black buttock cooking.pot | \glt ‘that woman, her skin is \textbf{black} (like) the bottom of a frying pan’ (Lit. ‘her skin is \textbf{black~black} (like) \textbf{the bottom} \ldots’)

Knowledge Point: Reduplicated verbs can also undergo an \isi{interpretational shift}. Such a shift can result in a nominal reading of reduplicated verbs, as in the elicited examples in (\ref{Example_4.49}) and (\ref{Example_4.50}), or an adverbial reading, as in (\ref{Example_4.51}) to (\ref{Example_4.53}).
Content 1: \gll tadi de pake \textbf{garo~garo} buat garo rumput | \gls earlier 3SG use RDP~scratch for scratch grass | \glt ‘earlier he took a \textbf{rake} to rake the grass’
Content 2: \gll sa gait mangga deng \textbf{gait~gait} | \gls 1SG hook mango with RDP~hook | \glt ‘I plucked mangoes with a \textbf{pole}’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{taw~taw} orang itu tida keliatang | \gls RDP~know person D.DIST NEG be.visible | \glt ‘\textbf{suddenly}, that person wasn’t visible (any longer)’
Content 4: \gll yo, pak Hendrik ini de bilang, mandi \textbf{cepat~cepat} | \gls yes father Hendrik D.PROX 3SG say bathe RDP~be.fast | \glt ‘yes, Mr. Hendrik here, he said, ``bathe \textbf{quickly}'''

Knowledge Point: Reduplicated verbs with a nominal reading typically denote the instrument of the action specified by the \isi{verbal base}, such as \textitbf{garo{\Tilde}garo} ‘rake’ (literally ‘\textsc{rdp}{\Tilde}scratch’) in (\ref{Example_4.49}) or \textitbf{gait{\Tilde}gait} ‘pole’ (literally ‘\textsc{rdp}{\Tilde}hook’) in (\ref{Example_4.50}).
Content 1: \gll tadi de pake \textbf{garo~garo} buat garo rumput | \gls earlier 3SG use RDP~scratch for scratch grass | \glt ‘earlier he took a \textbf{rake} to rake the grass’
Content 2: \gll sa gait mangga deng \textbf{gait~gait} | \gls 1SG hook mango with RDP~hook | \glt ‘I plucked mangoes with a \textbf{pole}’

Knowledge Point: Reduplicated verbs can also receive an adverbial reading, as in (\ref{Example_4.51}) to (\ref{Example_4.53}). Certain reduplicated dynamic verbs may take on the function as modal adverbs, such as \textitbf{taw{\Tilde}taw} ‘suddenly’ (literally ‘\textsc{rdp}{\Tilde}know’) in (\ref{Example_4.51}). Some reduplicated stative verbs are used as temporal adverbs such as \textitbf{lama{\Tilde}lama} ‘gradually’ (literally ‘\textsc{rdp}{\Tilde}be.long (of.duration)’) in (\ref{Example_4.52}), while others are used as manner adverbs, such as \textitbf{cepat{\Tilde}cepat} ‘quickly’ (literally ‘\textsc{rdp}{\Tilde}be.fast’) in (\ref{Example_4.53}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{taw~taw} orang itu tida keliatang | \gls RDP~know person D.DIST NEG be.visible | \glt ‘\textbf{suddenly}, that person wasn’t visible (any longer)’
Content 2: \gll yo, pak Hendrik ini de bilang, mandi \textbf{cepat~cepat} | \gls yes father Hendrik D.PROX 3SG say bathe RDP~be.fast | \glt ‘yes, Mr. Hendrik here, he said, ``bathe \textbf{quickly}'''
Content 3: \gll \textbf{taw~taw} orang itu tida keliatang | \gls RDP~know person D.DIST NEG be.visible | \glt ‘\textbf{suddenly}, that person wasn’t visible (any longer)’
Content 4: \gll \textbf{lama~lama} de padat itu macang aspal | \gls RDP~be.long 3SG be.solid D.DIST variety asphalt | \glt ‘\textbf{gradually}, it (the lime stone) becomes solid like asphalt’
Content 5: \gll yo, pak Hendrik ini de bilang, mandi \textbf{cepat~cepat} | \gls yes father Hendrik D.PROX 3SG say bathe RDP~be.fast | \glt ‘yes, Mr. Hendrik here, he said, ``bathe \textbf{quickly}'''

Knowledge Point: Reduplication of adverbs typically signals \isi{intensity}, similar to the \isi{reduplication} of verbs, discussed in §\ref{Para_4.2.2} (concerning the similarities between adverbs and verbs, see also §\ref{Para_5.4}). This is illustrated with the \isi{grading} ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{paling} ‘most’, the temporal ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{skarang} ‘now’, and the frequency ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{sring} ‘often’ in the three elicited examples in (\ref{Example_4.54}) to (\ref{Example_4.56}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll de bilang de mo kerja tapi \textbf{paling~paling} de tidor | \gls 3SG say 3SG want work but RDP~most 3SG sleep | \glt ‘he says, he wants to work but \textbf{most likely} he’ll sleep’
Content 4: \gll sa pu kaka \textbf{sring~sring} ke Jayapura | \gls 1SG POSS oSb RDP~often to Jayapura | \glt ‘my older sibling (travels) to Jayapura \textbf{very often}’

Knowledge Point: Reduplicated numerals have two meaning aspects. They may express \isi{collectivity} in the sense of ``all \textsc{base}' as in (\ref{Example_4.57}) and the elicited example in (\ref{Example_4.58}), or signal distributiveness in the sense of ``\textsc{base} by \textsc{base}'' as in (\ref{Example_4.59}) and (\ref{Example_4.60}).
Content 1: \gll yo, kas tinggal \textbf{dua~dua} | \gls yes give stay RDP~two | \glt ‘yes, let \textbf{both of them} stay’
Content 2: \gll ... karna pesta tu de su kasi mati \textbf{tiga~tiga} | \gls ... because party D.DIST 3SG already give die RDP~three | \glt ‘[he/she has three pigs (but)] because of that festivity he/she already killed \textbf{all three of them}’
Content 3: \gll ... jadi lega ada lepas~lepas \textbf{satu~satu} | \gls ... so be.relieved exist RDP~free RDP~one | \glt ‘[fortunately, (the people) over there have already received Jesus,] so (you can feel) relieved, they were freed \textbf{one-by-one}’
Content 4: \gll sa minum \textbf{lima~lima} mangkok | \gls 1SG drink RDP~five cup | \glt [About the lack of water during a retreat:] ‘I drank \textbf{five} cups (\textbf{every morning})’ (Lit. ‘\textbf{five-by-five} cups’)

Knowledge Point: Reduplicated quantifiers signal distributiveness, as in (\ref{Example_4.61}) and (\ref{Example_4.62}).
Content 1: \gll ... kariawang dong \textbf{banyak~banyak} dong baru turung ini | \gls ... employee 3PL RDP~many 3PL recently descend D.PROX | \glt [Waiting for other boat passengers:] ‘the employees came recently down(stream) \textbf{in groups of numerous people}’ (Lit. ‘\textbf{many-by-many}’)
Content 2: \gll dong blum isi, selaing dong isi \textbf{sedikit~sedikit} to? | \gls 3PL not.yet fill besides 3PL fill RDP~few right? | \glt [About how best to distribute food during a retreat:] ‘they haven’t yet filled (their plates), moreover \textbf{each one of them} (should) fill (their plates with) \textbf{little} (food), right?’ (Lit. ‘\textbf{little by little}’)

Knowledge Point: Reduplication of function words occurs considerably less often than that of content words. This section describes \isi{reduplication} of the following function words: personal pronouns (§\ref{Para_4.2.5.1}), demonstratives and locatives (§\ref{Para_4.2.5.2}), interrogatives (§\ref{Para_4.2.5.3}), and the \isi{causative} \isi{verb} \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’ and the \isi{reciprocity marker} \textitbf{baku} ‘\textsc{recp}’ (§\ref{Para_4.2.5.4}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: Not found

Knowledge Point: Personal pronouns can be reduplicated when used pronominally (for details on their different uses, see §\ref{Para_5.5} and §\ref{Para_6.1}). Reduplicated personal pronouns have three meaning aspects. Depending on the context, they signal \isi{collectivity}, disparagement, or \isi{imitation},\footnote{As mentioned in §\ref{Para_4.2.2.7}, the term ``\isi{imitation}'' includes meanings such as ``something is an \isi{imitation} of X'' or ``something is similar to X''.} as in (\ref{Example_4.63}) and in the elicited examples in (\ref{Example_4.64}) and (\ref{Example_4.65}), respectively.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: \gll \textbf{kamu~kamu} ini bangung bangung bangung bangung | \gls RDP~2PL D.PROX wake.up wake.up wake.up wake.up | \glt ‘\textbf{all of you} here wake-up, wake-up, wake-up, wake-up’
Content 5: \gll knapa \textbf{saya~saya} saja yang bapa kasi tugas | \gls why RDP~1SG just REL father give duty | \glt ‘why is it (always) \textbf{poor me} whom father gives chores’
Content 6: \gll \textbf{dorang~dorang} tra perna kasi bersi halamang | \gls RDP~3PL NEG ever give be.clean yard | \glt ‘\textbf{people like them} never clean (their) yard’

Knowledge Point: Demonstratives and locatives can also be reduplicated when used pronominally (for details on their different uses, see §\ref{Para_5.6} and §\ref{Para_5.7}, respectively). Reduplicated demonstratives express diversity as in (\ref{Example_4.66}) and (\ref{Example_4.67}).\footnote{Demonstrative sequences such as \textitbf{itu tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist} \textsc{d.dist}’ also convey \isi{intensity} or emphasis, as discussed in detail in §\ref{Para_7.1.2.3}. Given its phonological properties, however, juxtaposed \textitbf{itu tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist} \textsc{d.dist}’ is not taken as an instance of partial \isi{reduplication}. As discussed in §\ref{Para_4.1.2}, partial \isi{reduplication} of the stem \textitbf{itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}’ should result in the reduplicated form \textitbf{it{\Tilde}itu} ‘\textsc{d.dist}{\Tilde}\textsc{d.dist}’. Therefore, \textitbf{itu tu} ‘\textsc{d.dist} \textsc{d.dist}’ is taken as an instance of \isi{demonstrative} stacking (see §\ref{Para_5.6.4}).} Depending on the context, reduplicated locatives may signal diversity as in (\ref{Example_4.68}), or emphasize the core meaning of the respective \isi{locative}, as in (\ref{Example_4.69}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll setela itu nanti buat \textbf{ini~ini} | \gls after D.DIST very.soon make RDP~D.PROX | \glt ‘soon after that (they) did \textbf{these various} (things)’
Content 4: \gll ... yang laing \textbf{itu~itu} honorer smua itu | \gls ... REL be.different RDP~D.DIST be.honorary all D.DIST | \glt ‘[there are no school teachers, only him and Markus,] (as for) the others, \textbf{those various} (teachers) are all honorary (teachers)’
Content 8: \gll jadi de bapa ke Jayapura tinggal \textbf{situ~situ} | \gls so 3SG father to Jayapura stay RDP~L.MED | \glt ‘so her father (went) to Jayapura and lived \textbf{there in a number of different places}’
Content 9: \gll ... di sini ada air, mari \textbf{sini~sini} | \gls ... at L.PROX exist water hither RDP~L.PROX | \glt ‘[(you) may fish from up here,] here is water, (come) here, \textbf{right here}’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, interrogatives can be reduplicated when used pronominally (for details on their different uses, see §\ref{Para_5.8}). Reduplicated interrogatives signal \isi{indefiniteness} by referring to an unspecified group member, in the sense of ``any'' or ``Wh-ever''. This is illustrated with the examples in (\ref{Example_4.70}) to (\ref{Example_4.73}); the example in (\ref{Example_4.73}) is elicited.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll yo, tida bole kas taw \textbf{siapa~siapa} | \gls yes NEG may give know RDP~who | \glt ‘yes, (you) must not tell \textbf{anybody}’
Content 3: \gll di \textbf{mana~mana} smua pake ini, tajam besi ini | \gls at RDP~where all use D.PROX be.sharp metal D.PROX | \glt [About sagu production:] ‘\textbf{wherever} everybody uses it, this sharp metal’
Content 4: \gll di \textbf{mana~mana} smua pake ini, tajam besi ini | \gls at RDP~where all use D.PROX be.sharp metal D.PROX | \glt [About sagu production:] ‘\textbf{wherever} everybody uses it, this sharp metal’

Knowledge Point: Alternatively, speakers may use the bare \isi{interrogative} followed by the focus ad\isi{verb} \textitbf{saja} ‘just’ to encode an \isi{indefinite} referent, as discussed in §\ref{Para_5.8.8}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Reduplication of the \isi{causative} \isi{verb} \textitbf{kasi} ‘give’ and \isi{reciprocity marker} \textitbf{baku} ‘\textsc{recp}’, as in (\ref{Example_4.74}) and (\ref{Example_4.75}) respectively, signals \isi{repetition} or \isi{continuation}. (For more details on \isi{causative} and reciprocal constructions, see §\ref{Para_11.2} and §\ref{Para_11.3}, respectively.)
Content 1: \gll knapa kam \textbf{kas~kas} bangung dia, de masi mo tidor | \gls why 2PL RDP~give wake.up 3SG 3SG still want sleep | \glt ‘why do you \textbf{keep }waking him up?, he still wants to sleep’ (Lit. ‘\textbf{give~give} to wake up’)
Content 2: \gll itu sampe tong \textbf{baku~baku} tawar ini deng doseng | \gls D.DIST until 1PL RDP~RECP bargain D.PROX with lecturer | \glt ‘it got to the point that we and the lecturer were arguing \textbf{constantly with each other}’
Content 3: Not found
Content 4: Not found

Knowledge Point: Reduplication is also very common in other \ili{eastern Malay varieties}, such as \ili{Ambon Malay} (AM) \citep[112–140]{vanMinde.1997}, \ili{Banda Malay} (BM) \citep[160, 206]{Paauw.2009}, \ili{Kupang Malay} (KM) \citep[160, 171–173, 206, 252–253]{Paauw.2009}, \ili{Larantuka Malay} (LM) \citep[161, 171–173, 206, 256–258]{Paauw.2009}, \ili{Manado Malay} (MM) \citep[25–28]{Stoel.2005}, and \ili{Ternate Malay} (TM) \cite[136–139]{Litamahuputty.2012}. This section compares \isi{reduplication} across these Malay varieties in terms of \isi{lexeme formation} (§\ref{Para_4.3.1}), \isi{lexeme interpretation} (§\ref{Para_4.3.2}), and \isi{interpretational shift} (§\ref{Para_4.3.3}), as far as mentioned in the literature. For comparison, \isi{reduplication} in Papuan Malay (PM) is also included. Also included for comparison is \ili{Standard Indonesian} (SI) (\citealt{MacDonald.1976, Mintz.2002, Sneddon.2010}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: Not found

Knowledge Point: Two explanations present themselves for these observations. One explanation is that the commonalities between Papuan Malay and \ili{Ambon Malay}, together with the lack of overlap with the five other \ili{eastern Malay varieties}, are due to the distinct history of Papuan Malay, argued for in §\ref{Para_1.8}. An alternative explanation is that the differences among the \ili{eastern Malay varieties} are due to differing degrees of depth with which the different authors describe \isi{reduplication} in the Malay varieties presented in \tabref{Table_4.8}. This grammar on Papuan Malay, as well as that of \ili{Ambon Malay}, and also those of \ili{Standard Indonesian}, describe \isi{reduplication} as a \isi{word-formation} process rather thoroughly, while the descriptions of the five other \ili{eastern Malay varieties} mention only the most salient features of \isi{reduplication} in these varieties; hence, the rather large number of gaps in \tabref{Table_4.8}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Interpretational shift of reduplicated lexemes, as described for Papuan Malay (see §\ref{Para_4.2.1.4} and §\ref{Para_4.2.2.8}), is also attested for \ili{Ambon Malay} \citep[118, 123, 125]{vanMinde.1997}, \ili{Larantuka Malay} \citep[126, 270]{Paauw.2009}, \ili{Manado Malay} {\citep[26]{Stoel.2005}}, and \ili{Ternate Malay} {\citep[220]{Litamahuputty.2012}}.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Hence, in this grammar of Papuan Malay, the interpretational shifts described in §\ref{Para_4.2.1.4} and §\ref{Para_4.2.2.8} are taken to result from a slot filling-function of \isi{reduplication}. That is, \isi{reduplication} enables base words to fill different syntactic slots, such as an adverbial or a nominal slot.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: A comparison of \isi{reduplication} in Papuan Malay and six other \ili{eastern Malay varieties} shows that Papuan Malay shares many features with \ili{Ambon Malay}. In both varieties, \isi{reduplication} plays an important role. In Banda, Kupang, Manado, Larantuka, and \ili{Ternate Malay}, by contrast, \isi{reduplication} seems to be much less pervasive. These commonalities and differences may well point to the particular history of Papuan Malay, argued for in §\ref{Para_1.8}. The observed differences could, however, also result from gaps in the descriptions of Banda, Kupang, Manado, Larantuka, and \ili{Ternate Malay}.
Content 1: Not found
